modules.title: Phishing Detective
modules.description: Track down cybercriminals by identifying phishing attempts

steps.content: Welcome Detective! The city's been hit with a wave of phishing attacks. Your mission: identify the fake emails before they steal data.

steps.dialogue: We've intercepted 4 suspicious emails. Each one could be legitimate or a phishing attempt. Your job is to identify which ones are fake.

email.subject: ‚ö†Ô∏è Urgent: Password Expiring Today
email.body: Your password will expire in 2 hours. Click here to reset it immediately or lose access to your account.

steps.question: Is this email legitimate?

options.feedback: WRONG! Look at the domain - 'companye.com' not 'company.com'. This is a phishing attempt!
CORRECT! You spotted the fake domain. Real IT uses 'company.com' not 'companye.com'.
GOOD! When in doubt, always verify directly with IT.
Not ideal - you should learn to identify threats, not just delete everything.

steps.explanation: Phishers often use urgency and slight misspellings in domains to trick you.

email.subject: Your Order #78234 Has Been Placed
email.body: Thank you for your order of $2,847. If you didn't make this purchase, click here immediately.

helper.name: Security Bot
helper.tip: Check if you actually ordered anything. Scammers use fear to make you click!

steps.question: What should you do?

options.text: Click the link - I didn't order this!
options.feedback: STOP! Never click links when panicked. Go to Amazon.com directly.
PERFECT! Always go to the website directly, never through email links.
No! This confirms your email is active to scammers.
Good choice! Calling directly is a safe way to verify.

steps.explanation: Always verify suspicious orders through the official website or customer service.

email.subject: URGENT: Wire Transfer Needed
email.body: I'm in a meeting with a client. Please wire $50,000 to this account immediately. Don't reply - just do it!

steps.question: What's suspicious about this email?

options.feedback: DANGER! This is CEO fraud. Always verify large financial requests.
EXCELLENT! 'company-secure.com' isn't your company's domain. This is fraud!
CORRECT! Legitimate requests don't demand immediate action without verification.
NEVER wire money based on email alone! This loses millions for companies.

steps.explanation: CEO fraud scams cost companies billions. Always verify through a phone call.

steps.content: Congratulations Detective! You've identified the phishing attempts and kept the city safe.
steps.scoremessage: You earned {{score}} out of 100 Cyber Points!

modules.title: Password Guardian
modules.description: Defend against password attacks like a cyber knight

steps.content: The Kingdom of Cyberspace is under attack! Hackers are trying to break into accounts using weak passwords. You must defend the realm!

steps.question: Which password is STRONGEST?

options.feedback: Too common! This is in every hacker's dictionary.
EXCELLENT! Mix of cases, numbers, symbols, and length makes this strong.
Terrible! This is one of the most common password patterns.
Never use sequential numbers! Cracked in seconds.

steps.explanation: Strong passwords use: uppercase, lowercase, numbers, symbols, and are 12+ characters long.

steps.title: Password Manager Setup
steps.content: Your friend says: 'I use the same password everywhere so I don't forget it.'
steps.question: What advice do you give?

options.feedback: NO! If one site is hacked, ALL accounts are compromised!
PERFECT! Password managers create and store unique passwords safely.
Better than reusing, but physical notebooks can be lost or stolen.
NEVER! Personal info is easy for hackers to find.

steps.explanation: Password managers like LastPass, 1Password, or Bitwarden are essential for security.

steps.question: You get an email: 'Your password has expired. Click here to reset it.' What do you do?

options.feedback: STOP! This could be phishing. Never click email links for password resets.
PERFECT! Always navigate to sites directly, not through emails.
NEVER share your password via email! Huge security risk.
Better than clicking, but verify through the official site to be sure.

steps.explanation: Password reset phishing is extremely common. Always use the official website.

steps.question: How often should you change your passwords?

options.feedback: Too frequent! This leads to weak, predictable passwords.
CORRECT! Modern security says change only when compromised or annually.
Some periodic changes are good, especially for critical accounts.
Impractical! Focus on strong, unique passwords instead.

steps.explanation: Old advice said change frequently, but experts now say strong unique passwords are better.

steps.content: Victory! You've defended the Kingdom with your password knowledge!

modules.title: Malware Defender
modules.description: Spot and stop malware before it infects your system

steps.content: A virus outbreak is spreading through the internet! Your computer is the last line of defense. Can you spot the infected files before they take over?

steps.question: You download a file called 'invoice.pdf.exe'. What's wrong?

options.feedback: DANGER! The .exe extension means it's a program, not a PDF!
CORRECT! .exe files can contain malware. Real PDFs end in .pdf only.
NEVER open suspicious files! This could infect your computer.
SMART! Always scan downloads with antivirus before opening.

steps.explanation: Malware often uses double extensions to trick you. invoice.pdf.exe is a program, not a document!

steps.question: A pop-up says: 'Your computer is infected! Call this number immediately!' What do you do?

options.feedback: SCAM! This is fake tech support. Never call numbers from pop-ups.

options.text: Close the pop-up and run real antivirus
options.feedback: PERFECT! Use your installed antivirus, not random pop-ups.

options.text: Click the pop-up to fix it
options.feedback: NO! Clicking installs real malware. Close your browser instead.

options.text: Pay the fee to remove virus
options.feedback: SCAM! Legitimate antivirus doesn't demand immediate payment via pop-up.

steps.explanation: Fake virus pop-ups are scareware designed to make you panic and pay money.

steps.content: System secured! You've stopped the malware outbreak!

modules.title: Social Engineering Spotter
modules.description: Identify manipulation tactics used by cybercriminals

steps.content: Master manipulators are using psychology to trick people into giving up secrets. Your mission: spot their tactics before they succeed.

steps.question: Someone calls claiming to be from IT: 'I need your password to fix a problem.' What do you do?

options.feedback: NEVER! Real IT never asks for passwords. This is social engineering.

options.text: Hang up and call IT directly
options.feedback: PERFECT! Always verify by calling official numbers yourself.

options.text: Ask them to prove their identity
options.feedback: Better, but they'll just lie. Hang up and verify independently.
Don't engage with scammers. Just hang up and report it.

steps.explanation: Social engineers impersonate authority figures. Always verify through official channels.

steps.question: You find a USB drive in the parking lot. What do you do?

options.text: Plug it in to see what's on it
options.feedback: DANGER! USB drops are a common attack vector. Could contain malware.

options.text: Report it to security without plugging it in
options.feedback: EXCELLENT! USB drop attacks are real. Never plug in unknown drives.
NO! This could infect your personal computer too.
Better than using it, but report it so security can investigate.

steps.explanation: Attackers intentionally drop infected USB drives hoping someone will plug them in.

steps.question: Your 'boss' emails urgently: 'Buy 10 gift cards, scratch off codes, send photos of the codes to me.' What do you do?

options.feedback: SCAM! Real bosses never ask for gift cards. This is fraud.
CORRECT! Gift card scams are extremely common. Always verify.
Don't engage with the scammer. Verify through another channel.

options.text: Ask for a different payment method
options.feedback: NO! The entire request is fake. Don't try to help.

steps.explanation: Gift card scams have cost millions. Legitimate businesses never request gift cards.

steps.content: Mission accomplished! You've mastered social engineering defense!
